title: Joetta Shumba's mother explains the heartache of telling her grandson that his mummy was gone
text:
News Joetta Shumba's mother explains the heartache of telling her grandson that his mummy was gone "Zane was waiting for his mummy to come home and I had to tell him she was never coming back" Share Heartbroken mum Patricia Shumba (Photo: Julian Hamilton/Sunday Mirror) Share   
Patricia Shumba’s world fell in when police broke the news that a drink-driver had killed her daughter Joetta in a smash. 
The 25-year-old was sitting in the back of Martin Grant’s Audi S3 when the ­serial offender, who was three times the limit, ploughed into a lorry at 162mph. 
But while she struggled with her own pain she faced the added heartache of explaining to Joetta’s son Zane, then five, that he would never see his mum again. Joetta Shumba with her son, Zane (Photo: Sunday Mirror) 
Patricia, 49, speaking to the Sunday Mirror said : “Zane was waiting for his mummy to come home and I had to tell him she was never coming back. 
“I didn’t know what his reaction would be but I had to be honest because I didn’t want him to think there was a chance he’d see her again. He started to cry and said, ‘Is it because she doesn’t love me?’. That was the worst moment. Zane was Joetta’s world, she’d never have left him. Read More Driver in 160mph crash which killed mum Joetta Shumba 'wasn't capable of being in control of car' 
“I tried to tell him mummy was an angel in heaven but now he wants to go to heaven to visit her and it’s so difficult to explain that he can’t.” 
It emerged in court that Grant, 30, had previously been sentenced for a road rage attack, driving while banned and driving without insurance. He admitted causing death by dangerous driving and got eight years – but is only expected to serve four. 
A judge at Manchester crown court also banned him from driving for six years after his release. 
Call centre worker Patricia, who is now bringing up Zane, had expected him to be charged with manslaughter, which can mean life behind bars. Read More Heartbroken mum of Joetta Shumba killed in '160mph smash' says she sees her daughter in her dreams 
The mum-of-three, from Stockport, Gtr Manchester, is now calling for killer drink-drivers to get tougher sentences. She also wants longer bans for motoring crimes, to prevent similar tragedies. 
Patricia said: “The law is wrong when it comes to dangerous driving and I feel like it protects the defendant more than the victim. 
“I don’t understand why the driver wasn’t charged with manslaughter. I was told the maximum sentence would be 12 years but he’s likely to serve four. It doesn’t make sense. 
“I don’t understand why he was on the road when Joetta was killed but one day he will be allowed to drive again.” 
HR worker Joetta had given her mum a hug before she left the family home in a taxi for a night out in Manchester on January 23 last year. Read More Man pleads guilty to causing crash death of young mum Joetta Shumba 
Zane, now six, was being looked after by his other grandparents. When Joetta failed to return home the next morning, Patricia assumed she had stayed with a friend. 
Then she saw a headline about the accident on the news, never thinking it could have claimed her girl’s life. She said: “I saw the news but I didn’t think about it. I assumed Joetta was at a friend’s and she’d call in a few hours to ask me for a lift home. I started to worry at 1pm, when I spoke to Zane’s other grandma, who said she hadn’t phoned to check on him. That was unlike her. I knew something was wrong.” 
Patricia reported Joetta missing and it was almost 24 hours before officers discovered she was the victim of the M62 smash, between Eccles and Warrington. 
Grant, who suffered a leg injury, tried to leave hospital before he was arrested. He prolonged the family’s agony by ­refusing to name his dead passenger. Patricia said: “I don’t know how well they knew each other. I’d never heard of him. He didn’t say who was in the car. Maybe he thought it would help his case. Read More Friends of young mum Joetta Shumba killed in motorway smash launch fundraising appeal for her five-year-old son 
“Maybe he was in shock. But he has put himself first. Why didn’t he think about her family? Joetta deserved better.” 
Police finally identified Joetta thanks to descriptions Patricia gave them of her jewellery. She then had to break the news to Zane and her other daughters Chipo, 19, and Jessica, 13. Her husband Harrison, 51, a chemical engineer, was working in South Africa and had to fly home. 
The next day, she went to identify Joetta’s body in a morgue. Patricia said: “She was behind glass I couldn’t touch her. Her head was in bandages. She didn’t look like herself but I could see it was her. I wanted to hold her but I couldn’t. I asked to see her hand as she has a birthmark like mine but there were too many cuts.” (Photo: Sunday Mirror) 
The family had to wait a month before holding Joetta’s funeral as Grant’s defence team wanted a second postmortem. Patricia was tortured by thoughts of her girl’s last moments. “There were so many unanswered questions,” she said. “I just hoped it had been quick. She had been drinking, so I hoped she had been asleep. 
“I couldn’t bear to think of the alternative as it makes me even more upset. She hated speeding and was always telling her dad and me to slow down.” Read More Friends and colleagues of Joetta Shumba launch fundraising appeal to help young mum's family 
Patricia could not bear to attend court in May to see Grant, from Birmingham, sentenced. He has not reached out to say sorry but she has toyed with the idea of visiting him in jail to get some answers. 
She said: “Some days, I want answers, others I don’t want to open that can of worms. I don’t think the answers will make me feel better. They won’t be pretty. 
“If I do it, it will be for our benefit and not his. I don’t want to portray him as a monster as he has to live with what he did and anyone with a conscience would find that very difficult. I want him punished in a way that deters him from driving dangerously again. (Photo: Sunday Mirror) 
“Maybe he should see children who lost parents. I’d like him to have counselling and to write essays on what he has done. 
“He will be allowed to drive again but can he be cured? He made a conscious decision to drive drunk and do the speed he was doing. Maybe it would be safer, given his history, if he never drove again.” 
Patricia is focusing on keeping Joetta’s memory alive for Zane. She has had help from child bereavement charity Once Upon a Smile to help explain things. Yet she cannot bear to take him to his mum’s grave in case he feels rejected again. Read More Man charged with causing death by dangerous driving over crash that killed Joetta Shumba 
She said: “We talk to Zane about his mummy and if he is good we tell him mummy will be proud. He still dreams about her a lot. I haven’t taken him to the grave as I don’t know what to tell him. He won’t understand why he can’t see her and he wants to be where his mummy is. 
“One day we are going to have to explain exactly what happened but I don’t want him to be scared of cars. It’s very hard when he questions why she left him, because she never wanted to.” Like us on Facebook
